(I'm referring to when all the gen a/i started a couple years ago, not our particular conversation)

I just didn't agree with the digital vs film camera comparison. I've been in... a lot... a looot of arguments, conversations, considerations, and I've yet to see anything that really, truly equates. I tried to play "open minded carefully considerate"  at first but it didn't work out. I'm tired.

I am HERE for this! I'm ready to read the heck out of it omg. I love the tone, too, it sounds like you're ready to school some people who desperately need it

I don't think that's an accurate comparison though. A photographer still works the camera in both cases. Trust me when I say I've thought about all the angles and there is no real comparison on gen a/i 
There's always been a little distrust with new tech (digital artists know this) but this is big

Haha appreciate it. I try not to openly rant about a/i *too* much though because I got my fill of viral craziness on Twitter. I think the block lists I'm subbed to here will help mitigate most of the worst of them though. Hopefully lol
People already do art for fun

Yeah, it's just after years of debates, pointless is where I've landed. They always have some argument to justify it.
Pointless b/c it's theft. Pointless because they didn't actually make it. Pointless because it solves no real problems outside of capitalist greed. Pointless b/c enviro damage. Etc
I'd really like a detailed explanation of why it's interesting, but something tells me it's not a long one.

It's possible, but the video was saying she saw fading within days of direct light exposure. To me that says it might change regardless of the type of glass (but hard to be sure). I personally decided not to use it anymore and plan to mix the light-fast dupe.

I'm living for these every time you post! Looks like a really nice day too
It's why there's that saying; ideas are a dime a dozen. A/i is for the people who don't want to do the hardest part of art; actually making it.

There's been a few floating around now, though this one today was a much smaller artist so I don't want to publicly blast (I don't know them directly). Jef Bourgeau is constantly coming across my feed lately, then there's that DC comic with the joker. Most I see in that a/i know your rights group

The amount of money a/i companies have put into their marketing is staggering to say the least. But I've seen far too many out of touch artists look at it as "oh yeah it's cool and helps creativity! It's not so bad it's "aLl iN hOw YoU uSe It". (while totally ignoring all the harm it does)

Yeah, a big digital artist I used to know prided in that fact of their digital paintings being highly collectible, even claiming traditional art would "die out" (lolll). The whole thing felt like a big crypto scam, and kinda was.

Hmm, art has been just as consumable as music. If anything for longer than music, considering how long recording devices have existed vs. paintings. The key will be how we as artists continue to create and not fall to this idea that new tech automatically means something better.

When I saw that original article I cringed so hard at the 'content to mine' and how a/i was 'exciting' parts. These are two huge red flags, and I don't know if I can believe that Wizards will ban a/i until they put out an official statement. I just really need to see it in stone, ya know? :/
They honestly just don't understand it, or don't care, or give XYZ justification, etc. Honestly established artists that use gen a/i can go ahead and un-establish themselves as artists.
Eeexactly

I know there are certain artists who crowed about NFT's as the future, pushed them so hard only to quietly remove them from their profiles and websites when it all crashed lol. I wish a/i generated images would go the same exact way.

I'm so beyond exhausted at the "it's unavoidable" comment, because all you have to do is... not... use it. It's a choice, not a requirement. 
Sorry all, that's my one rant for the week I promise lol

I keep seeing more established older artists turning to a/i generated images as " unavoidable". 
Dude. It's VERY avoidable. I've never used oil paint in my life but I get by just fine as an artist. 
Then they post this a/i crap & say "interesting image".
No, it's not interesting. It's pointless.

It took me a very long time not just to understand it but to really take action on it. I have a project that no one has ever seen. It's utterly mine, and I *love* working on it, even if I never share it with anyone but my future self. It's a type of indulgence that I think we all could use more of.
I'm glad you were able to find the parts you enjoy again <3

There's something really amazing that happens. At least for me it's a relief to know that I can change anything in a painting at any time, simply because I feel like, because I want to. It's a true kind of freedom that removes all the boundaries :)

This is so very valid! It's a healthy way to do it, imo.
I used to take on a lot of character commissions but it started to weigh on me. When I found a day job that paid better, I was able to do more of the art I wanted and I felt happier for it.

As I entered high school and college, the thought of working on a team and contributing my hand to a project was the most thrilling thing ever! But I still had my own ideas I wanted to bring to life. Never did that urge to fulfill my own wishes stop. I'm most satisfied when I explore my own ideas

After that post yesterday I just keep thinking about it.
Artists should be more selfish in what we do. When I wanted to be an artist as a kid, I never thought to myself "I want to bend to the whims of what other people want me to make." Instead I wanted to make the things I saw in MY imagination
You took a big first step, you got this.
Too bad Styx didn't influence them enough to understand their experiences are not more special than other peoples', just the one they happened to be born into. But that's just my thoughts on that lol
I feel this. I swear it's always the springtime when everything seems to happen/need to be done all at once
You're absolutely a writer! Time to put it in the bio and make it official

That's probably why I didn't respond well to sentences that start with "you should paint ___". I'm selfish in that I have the ability to paint whatever I want and I plan to do as much of it as I can lol. I think all artists should be a little more selfish that way
I might have just accidentally said the same thing as OP, so I'm just saying I wholeheartedly agree. x]
And I mean yes absolutely Miyazaki is an artist, lol, I'm just including not only film and animation but 2D drawing, painting, everything in with this idea :)

This is about Miyazaki but it's true for artists. The work we're passionate about will shine differently than what fits the norm, the standard, the "general audience". We need to do work for *us*, to feed our souls. Those it connects to will respond stronger to it as well

Oh my gosh! Communication is *key* and SO important. When I'm talking about quotes I always insist on making sure the timeline is clear and doable - and notify of any delay right away. I'll even refuse a client if I'm worried I can't make a deadline with time to spare 😅

Also very good point about the quality of interactions! The ability to subscribe to block lists that include bots really helps prevent hollow interactions.

I don't really know them so it wasn't a time investment I could really justify at the time. I feel like Twitter is largely bots and inactive accounts making up follower counts, too. I mean, I'm no longer active and I still follow a ton of people there, so even my own follow isn't "real" anymore.

I wasn't able to stick around to show them it might be worth it to switch, but also it's another example of how far that place has gone down as far as reach. If someone with 32k followers can't reach more than me with 1.5k, it's a doomed platform. It's hard to restart, but also... why stay then?

I asked someone at ECCC who I've followed for a long time on Twitter if they had a BlueSky account and they said no. I told them I left Twitter. They said they can't leave because it's the only place they get traction. They have over 32k followers, and they get the same traction there as I do here.

Yup it's exactly like that! If I know I need to work longer I'll find something that is like an hour or so and tell myself I have to go until that thing stops. Music albums are usually a great length for this, or podcasts.

#2 Is to kickstart the drive, kind of like having to prime a motor. I may not be feeling up to painting for a long time, but painting for 10 minutes, or 20 with an episode of a TV show I can do. 99% of the time I keep painting. Sometimes my brain isn't in it and I try it again after a break.

For #1, when I have a painting in progress I'll fill my water cups with clean water and set everything out so it's ready to go the next day. Removing the barrier of having to get ready makes it easier (and more tempting) to have my first action be painting instead of prep.

QRP with your loading screen art tip:

When you're having trouble getting motivated to start try;

1 - Keeping your work area ready with everything you need before you even plan to start.
2 - Play something (vid/music) that's 10-20 minutes long, and work until it ends. Keep going if you feel like it

I just added a few more posts with more info on how to utilize tags, search and ALT text.

For art, joining in art shares is always good too
bsky.app/profile/did:...

Then you want to follow this feed. It'll show only people you follow. Click on "pin to home" and it'll appear at the top of your page for phone, and right side for desktop.
bsky.app/profile/did:...

And finally, searching!
Hashtags are for feeds, not for searching. Instead you can only search general words. For example don't search for #dragon, search just the word dragon. It's not perfect, but it finds everything. Use this to your advantage when making posts. It will pull from ALT text too!

To share a feed
Go to menu, feeds, upper right three dots, share feed. This just copies the web address.

Here are some good ones I like:
Only Posts: bsky.app/profile/did:...
The Gram: bsky.app/profile/did:...
For You: bsky.app/profile/did:...
Alt- Popular with friends: bsky.app/profile/did:...

On finding new feeds.
People can share feeds, you can use the built-in feed finder, or my favorite is this finder. 
goodfeeds.co
Do you mind linking to those? I actually don't have them!

Some feeds have built in filters, like The Gram for ex. will show you ONLY the posts with images from those you follow. Some feeds use hashtags to filter, like #FantasyArt for example. Use hashtags for your posts to be included in tagged feeds.
Some feeds are made by BluesSky, some by users

A quick tip about hashtags, feeds and searches for Blue Sky!

Feeds are what you subscribe to in order to find new stuff you are interested in. Your pinned feeds appear at the top of your page. You have control over what feeds you see. You can sub to as many as you want. Unsub from ones you don't. 🗑️

As an artist I say these things because I need to get this across. I *want* authors to be successful. If I make a book cover for you I really want it to be successful! My goal is to uphold everyone who values real creativity and authenticity.

As creators we're often made to feel like our work isn't worthy if it isn't extremely complex. I just wanted to say that you don't have to stop yourself from making something because you feel it's not detailed enough, or awe inspiring, or the "best" of anything. 
Simple can still be great.

Something I keep thinking about lately is how many things don't HAVE to be complex to be enjoyable or good.
Art. Books. Food. Movies. 
It's too easy to think we have to make everything the next masterpiece of complexity, and we get hung up in this idea that it won't be good unless it lives up to xyz

I know that a lot of people hate Chrome, & that's fine, it's got a lot of issues. But it's currently what I'm using so it's all I can help with. AI generated images will not magically disappear by using another search engine unfortunately. Sorry I can't do more, but a little is better than nothing.

To clarify  some things because I've seen it mentioned a few times;
I only mentioned Google search because that's what these search functions work in. I don't how the other search engines work,  hence I can't help there.
Yes, there are other SE's.
Alternative SE's will have the same ai image issues
You should test it and find out ;)

New artists usually aren't discovered through Google search, since results are based on click counts. As always new artists will find the best reach through online galleries and social media. This hasn't actually changed much, but artists looking for reference will definitely need these search tools

This is going to impact all search engines, unfortunately. It's the entire web as we know it, at least until legislation passes that requires imprints that mark an image as ai generated (or something to that degree)
Was it ever. I honestly wish I had figured a lot of it out sooner, how to take advantage of it all, but I can still look back and see how different things were.

I graduated college in 2008 so that was naturally my starting point, and it was definitely a rough start lol. Wasn't until like, 2014 or so that I found online art communities to really help branch out. But it's true... the internet really worked for us in a lot of ways.
Also valid!

Excellent! It's unfortunate that we have to do this, but I'm glad it will help navigate some of the worst of it.
I remember the days when we were only told to avoid Wikipedia because "anyone could put anything"... but at least that was somewhat user reviewed
For stock images you'll want to use the before:2023 option. Sucks that it'll filter out recently uploaded images, but you'll be able to find authentic stock images that way
Happy to help!
Oh that's cool!
Aw heck well I'm glad it'll help! I'm no genie, just passing on some information I learned just today as well 😊

The second option of search won't exclude all ai generated images because it also pulls from POD and stock sites which are inundated with them and incorrectly tagged. But, it will filter most out so you can hopefully find what you're looking for! I hope this helps someone out there

Friends! Here's how to remove ai from your google searches using the example; fantasy horse 

Fantasy horse, before:2023 
Brings up everything posted ONLY before the year 2023 

Fantasy horse, -ai -prompt -stock -openai 
Gets rid of MOST generative images and includes current/recent images

That being said, I want to give myself a creative outlet that's just for me where I don't feel the pressure to have to share. I used to love writing when I was in high school - poetry too. It feel like a lost art I want to get back.

It's funny how similar this mindset is to doing art, except with art I have no problem with continuing on through the bad stuff to get to some good stuff. But with writing all you *ever* see is the finished product - no sketches, wip, failed attempts. I need to remember it's still there, too.

One of the best thing's I've heard about writing is "the first draft is always shit".
It takes the pressure off of feeling like I could never do it because it would be *bad*. But maybe, possibly it wouldn't be bad, if I got past the first draft? 
I like this idea a lot. I want to write stuff again.

As an artist I can book out projects a year in advance, and do. Whether freelance or my own projects, conventions or trips, my calendar can fill fast. Plan to find your artist months ahead of when you actually need them - it'll give you more options and help you avoid rush fees.

A quick fyi to #authors even *thinking* of getting a cover artist.

But even my Pixel 6 phone camera captured noticeably better quality shots (without the zoom obviously). 
Since I use photos for reference, color and clarity is paramount. The SX60 is decent enough, really good for video, but not what I want in the end

The two main reasons I'm hesitant to use the SX60 is that it doesn't do well in low light - it gets really grainy. It also doesn't do well with contrast - lights are blown out the point that color gets lost in the sky for example. I've tried everything from manual to automatic, to scenic modes.

Even though I've had to sacrifice zoom down to just 5x, I'm hoping the quality will allow me to get lots of great reference photos. You know, because I'm an artist and literally everything is about gathering references. I only have 48 GB, it's not nearly enough! 😂

Yeah, in it's like a speed challenge for some people lol. Easier to do in AA than exhibitor hall which is where I am though.

Oh gosh, trying to do shows without a car is such a monumental feat all on its own! Seriously props to everyone who can manage it. I know some artists that would rent or borrow a vehicle for a show. For a while I was doing up to 12 a year, so not having a car would have been impossible 😱
Sometimes I still can't believe I used to do conventions and then go out for gatherings until late in the evening like how did I survive lol

I mostly do local shows now partly because it's just me. I solo drive there, solo set up, solo drive back. If I'm lucky I might have company on the drive at least if another artist friend is doing the same show as me then we ride together.

Yeah that's so true. It all has to be factored into what I need to sell at a show to make it worth doing. A 3 day show is actually 4 days including setup day. A four day show... oof, I don't like 4 day shows. I envy the folks that set up in like an hour lol

YES. It's my dream to have someone else set up my booth haha. I'm usually there 4-5 hours doing it because I only get assistants for during show hours. Honestly, packing up is the worst - already tired and then have to drive home 😩

I've actually never caught the con crud (or the C crud!) from a convention because I'm incredibly strict about hygiene - and these days masking. Though even then I'm dog tired at the end of it and need 2-3 days to recover lol

I seriously want to hire someone to run my booth these days, it's just so exhausting lol. I used to have no problem being in high-energy social mode for 3 days straight, but doing that along with all the packing and moving heavy boxes, setting up and tearing down (by myself usually). Is lot.

I've wanted to try doing acrylic pours for a while now! Some of them are just absolutely gorgeous. I love to paint representational themes, but there's something so pleasing about the flow of colors and shapes, too. Kind of like when I'm playing with a new paint, I just want to witness the color
